subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... It s definitely not just for your own sake. I m following this very closely. ... I like these changes, especially with Roar. ... I just talked to someone
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
>
> Being a visual learner, I've put up what I hope visually captures the
> latest ideas discussed. I'll keep changing them as our notions evolve
> if only for my own sake.

It's definitely not just for your own sake. I'm following this very
closely.


> I've made changes that, among other things:
> - reflect the latest thinking about Roe (namely that it is being
> treated as a pseudo-diphthong)
> - reflect the SQUARE NEAR suggestion

I like these changes, especially with Roar.

>
> I think the "pen" "pin" issue is not a total KIT DRESS merger but just
> something that happens before "n". Such people will hear "pen" with
> the KIT sound and thus use #26 I've omitted it from the upload until
> we get a clearer idea.

I just talked to someone from E. Kentucky today, and she says she makes
no distinction between "pen" and "pin." But of course, both of those
words have n after the vowel.

/west_coast_us.jpg>
>
> American English as represented by Carnegie Mellon University
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/typical_us.jpg
> <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/typical_us.jpg>
>
> New Zealand accent. I have no expertise in this accent: it was built
> purely from looking up the NZ lexical sets and applying the rules
> we've put together. As such it can show us if what we're doing makes
> sense and maybe what we can (or can not) get from using lexical sets.
>


Okay. I compared the NZ chart to the American one. They seem consistent,
which is what we aimed for--the same letters take the same sets. I don't
know if a New Zealender would necessarily agree with the choices, of
course; I have no idea about this accent.

As you probably saw, I posted my own chart. We seem to be working at
cross purposes. But, just having a look at your chart again, I see we
are pretty much in complete agreement with the exception that you put
LOT under Ah, whereas I put it under On and added an explanation at the
end as to what users should do when merging Ah Awl and On.

If I'm not mistaken, the biggest problem facing us right now is what to
do with mergers. I don't hear the difference between "beer" and "bear,"
so how do I write this word? Do I write it as I hear it, but for more
formal writing look up its *pronounciation* (not spelling!) in a
standard dictionary? I think we have debated this issue quite a bit, and
with good reason, considering it is our biggest obstacle. I'm open to
any suggestions on how to deal with mergers.

>
> > Since there are only eight lexical sets and 15 vowels, there will need
> > to be some more or less arbitrary conventions to determine which vowel
> > is used to write which set.
>
> This must be done with the utmost care:

Sorry to be dense, but I don't follow. There are many more sets than
15--in fact, more than there are vowels.

> >
> > "Kyor?" That couldn't be anything but "cure", so I wouldn't have
> trouble
> > with it.
>
> But is this a significant improvement over Et+Key+See+Et+No+Tea for
> "accent". I'm not being glib, it is an important question: I want to
> make sure we are not trading known problems for unknown ones.

Wouldn't you actually write it Kick Yo-yo Wool Roar? That is exactly as
I hear it.

I'll not do any more work on my chart, since yours reflect a deeper
understanding and we seem to have produced nearly the same chart anyway.

Thanks for all your hard work

Paul
